bibl.title: Letter from Oscar Dowling to Henry Rose Carter, March 26, 1917

div1.p: Dowling informs Carter that there has been no increase of malaria associated with timber operations in swampland.

div1.head: Letter from Oscar Dowling to Henry Rose Carter, March 26, 1917

NEW ORLEANS, LA. March 26,, 1917.
Dr. H. R. Carter, Assistant Surgeon General,
United States Public Health Service,
Baltimore, Md.,
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
Your letter of recent date regarding
the cutting of lumber in cypress swamps, received.

Per your request of February 13th.,
I wrote to the lumber Companies situated at Bowie, La., Donner,
Jeanerette, Garyville, Lutcher, and Plaquemine. From the
various replies received from these companies, the concensus
of opinion is that the cutting of lumber in the swamps has not
increased malaria; that it has had no bearing on the malarial
situation. In answer to your inquiry - “I would especially
ask if this has been true of the lumber operations of the
Williams Cypress Co. of Patterson, La.” - I quote the following
from Dr. W. D. Roussel's letter - “The Company in question
operates only in cypress swamps, but with their usual pre-
cautions of screening their camps they have mimimized malarial
infection to a noticeable extent. We have just recently
taken over the care of the Skidder Camps about 30 miles from
this town, and we will be better able to give you an intelligent
report in the next six months”.

Trusting the above will serve your
